content.text: On Fig. 1.1, mark a point P where the acceleration of the car is zero
the speed of the car at time \(t = 15s\)
the average speed of the car between time \(t = 30s\) and time \(t = 45s\)
average speed = .........
Determine:
At time \(t = 45s\) , the car starts to decelerate. At time \(t = 55s\) and at a distance of \(400m\) from the starting point, the car stops. It then remains stationary for 5.0s
On Fig. 1.1, draw a possible continuation of the distance-time graph
[Total: 8]
Fig. 1.1 is the distance-time graph for a moving car
Complete Fig. 2.1 by writing in the right-hand column the name of the quantity given by the product in the left-hand column
Calculate:
1. the momentum of the ball as it leaves the golf club
momentum = .........
2. the average resultant force acting on the ball while it is in contact with the golf club
average force = .........
While the golf club is in contact with the ball, the ball becomes compressed and changes shape
State the type of energy stored in the ball during its contact with the golf club
[Total: 7]
Fig. 2.2 shows a man hitting a ball with a golf club
The ball has a mass of \(0.046 \text{kg}\). The golf club is in contact with the ball for \(5.0 \times 10^{-4} \text{s}\) and the ball leaves the golf club at a speed of \(65 \text{m/s}\)
State the name of the instrument
State what is in space A
Calculate the atmospheric pressure
Fig. 3.1 shows an instrument that is being used to determine the atmospheric pressure
Fig. 3.2 shows mercury stored in a cylindrical glass jar of internal radius 4.0 cm. The depth of mercury in the jar is 12 cm
Calculate the weight of mercury in the jar
The density of mercury is \(1.4 \times 10^{4} \text{kg} / \text{m}^{3}\)
The wavelength of the wave is \(0.030 \text{m}\)
Calculate the frequency of the wave
frequency = .........
Explain what is meant by the term transverse wave motion
Draw a diagram that represents a transverse wave travelling from left to right across the page. On your diagram, label:
• the wavelength
• the amplitude
[Total: 8]
This water wave is a transverse wave
A wave is travelling across the surface of water in a tank at a speed of \(0.15 \text{m/s}\)
A student is supplied with a small block of iron, a thermometer and an electrical heater of power \(P\)
There are two holes drilled in the iron block. The heater fits tightly into one hole and the student places the thermometer into the other hole
Fig. 5.1 shows the equipment
The student uses this equipment when determining the specific heat capacity of iron
State:
• the other equipment the student will need
• the measurements the student needs to take
• the equation used when calculating the value of the specific heat capacity of iron
State what is meant by the thermal capacity of an object
The specific heat capacity of iron is \(460 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\)
Calculate the thermal capacity of the wood-burning stove
thermal capacity = .........
[Total: 7]
In the student's home there is a wood-burning stove, which is also made of iron. The mass of the wood-burning stove is \(85 \text{kg}\)
From point X on Fig. 6.1, draw a ray of red light, labelled R and a ray of violet light, labelled V, to show how a spectrum is formed on the screen. [2]
State the colour of light in the visible spectrum with the shortest wavelength
Fig. 6.1 shows white light incident at point X on a glass prism
Describe and explain what happens to the ray of light in Fig. 6.2 as it strikes side AC of the prism
Describe and explain what happens to the ray of light in Fig. 6.3 as it strikes the glass at point Y
[Total: 9]
The critical angle for a type of glass is \(42^{\circ}\)
Fig. 6.2 and Fig. 6.3 show two prisms ABC and PQR made of this type of glass. A ray of monochromatic red light passes into each of the prisms
State how the structure of an electrical insulator differs from the structure of a conductor
Suggest why the handles are made from an electrical insulator
Explain, in terms of the particles involved, how one contact becomes negatively charged and how the other contact becomes positively charged
The defibrillator passes a charge of \(9.1 \times 10^{-3} \text{C}\) through the medical dummy in \(6.5 \times 10^{-4} \text{s}\)
Calculate the average current in the dummy
current = .........
A defibrillator is a machine that sends an electrical charge through the heart of a patient whose heart is not beating correctly. Doctors learn to use a defibrillator by practising on a medical dummy
Fig. 7.1 shows the two contacts of a defibrillator attached to a medical dummy

The contacts that touch the dummy are made from metal, and when the defibrillator is being used, one contact becomes strongly negatively charged and the other contact becomes strongly positively charged. The handles of the contacts are made from plastic, which is an electrical insulator
State the energy changes that are taking place in the circuit
the current in the \(120\Omega\) resistor
current = .........
the potential difference (p.d.) across wire P
the resistance of wire P
resistance = .........
The reading on the voltmeter is 2.4V
Calculate:
Wire P has a diameter \(d\) and a length \(l\) . A second piece of wire Q is made of the same material as P
The diameter of wire Q is \(0.50 \times d\) and its length is \(5.0 \times l\)
Calculate the resistance of wire Q
resistance = .........
A 9.0V battery is connected to a \(120\Omega\) resistor in series with wire P
Fig. 8.1 shows a voltmeter connected across the \(120\Omega\) resistor
Describe how a direct current (d.c.) differs from an alternating current (a.c.)
On Fig. 9.2, sketch a graph to indicate how the current in the heater varies with time
Calculate the power produced by the heater when the current is 0.75A
Fig. 9.1 shows how the voltage output of an a.c. generator varies with time
A heater is connected directly to the a.c. generator and the maximum current in the heater is 0.75A
On Fig. 9.3, draw a straight arrow to indicate the direction in which side AB of the coil is moving. Label this arrow M. [1]
Deduce the direction of the current induced in side AB of the coil and explain your reasoning
The rate at which the coil of the a.c. generator rotates increases
State **two** ways in which the alternating voltage changes
Fig. 9.3 shows the coil ABCD of the a.c. generator between two magnetic poles
Complete the nuclide equation for this decay
A pure sample of thorium-234 emits \(\beta\) -particles at a count rate of 2480 counts/second. The half-life of thorium-234 is 24 days
Calculate the count rate for the emission of \(\beta\) -particles from the thorium in the sample after 72 days have passed
count rate .........
The isotope of protactinium in **(a)** is also radioactive. It decays by \(\beta\) -emission and has a half-life of 70 seconds
State and explain how this would affect the **observed** count rate for the sample in **(b)** after 72 days
[Total: 8]
Thorium-234 ( \(^{234}_{90}\mathrm {Th}\)) is radioactive. It decays by \(\beta \)-emission to form an isotope of protactinium (Pa)
